verses.verse: Now three days after Festus had come into the province, he came up from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
Then the high priest and the Jewish leaders laid out their case against Paul, and encouraged
and begged him [to do] a favor against [Paul}) that he [Festus] would send him to Jerusalem--for they had an ambush to kill him on the way.
But Festus answered that Paul should be kept at Caesarea and that he, himself, would be leaving [for there] shortly.
"Therefore let them who are able among you," he said, "come down with me and accuse this man, if there is any wickedness in him."
After he stayed among them for more than ten days, he went down to Caesarea and on the next day sitting on the judgment seat commanded Paul to be brought in.
After he arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him and brought many serious charges against Paul, which they could not prove.
But Paul made his own defense, "Nothing against the Law of the Jews, against the Temple, or even against Caesar have I committed any thing wrong."
But Festus wanting to do a favor for the Jews answered Paul, "Will you go up with me to Jerusalem and be tried of these charges before me?"
Then Paul answered, "I ought to be tried at Caesar's judgment seat. I have done no wrong to the Jews as you know very well.

"For if I am an wrongdoer or have committed anything worthy of death, I don't refuse to die, but if there are none of these things that they accuse me of, no one can hand me over to them. I appeal to Caesar."
Then Festus after talking it over with the council, answered, "Have you appealed to Caesar? Then to Caesar you will go."
Some time later King Agrippa and Bernice came to Caesarea to welcome Festus.
After they had been there a few days, Festus informed Paul's situation to the king, saying, "There is a certain man left a prisoner here by Felix,
and when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the Jewish elders told me about him, requesting that I would condemn him.

"I answered them, «It is not the Roman's way to hand over any one to die before he who is accused have the accusers face to face [with him] and have permission to defend himself about the crime laid against him.»
"Therefore when they came here, I sat the next day on the judgment seat without delay and commanded that the man be brought in.
"When the accusers stood up against him, they didn't bring evil crimes like I thought [they would],
but had certain arguments against him about their own superstitions and one about a Jesus who was dead, but Paul claimed to be alive.
"Because I was at a loss of such questions, I asked him if he would go to Jerusalem and be tried there about these things.
"But after Paul had appealed to be kept under guard for the decision of the Emperor, I commanded him to be kept under guard until I could sent him to Caesar."
Then Agrippa said to Festus, "I would like also hear the man myself." "Tomorrow," he said, "you will hear him."

On the next day after Agrippa and Bernice had come with pomp and entered in the audience hall along with the chief captains and the prominent men of the city, Paul was brought out at Festus' commandment.

Festus said, "King Agrippa and all men who are here with us, you are seeing the man about whom all the multitude of the Jews have been dealing with me both at Jerusalem and here shouting that he should not live any longer.
"But after I found that he had committed nothing worthy of death and that he had appealed to the Emperor, I decided to send him.
"I have nothing definite to write to my lord. Therefore I have brought him out to you and especially to you King Agrippa, so that after your examination, I might have something to write.
"For it seems unreasonable to me to send a prisoner and not specify the crimes against him."
